interaction_summary:
=== Purchase Information === Review Date: 2019/12/12 Average Rating: 4.6 Product Details: {'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['David Batty'], 'Producers': ['Simon Fuller', 'Michael Caine', 'Dick Clement', 'Ian La Frenais', "Fodhla Cronin O'Reilly"], 'Starring': ['David Bailey', 'Michael Caine', 'Joan Collins'], 'Studio': ['Gravitas Ventures']} Review Text: I mean....

I get that at the end of your life you want to look back, see what it was, remember why it was, relive the good times. It’s just that the rest of us have had to live your particular good time along with you for over fifty bleeding years, and it’s been incredibly damaging. Freedom, self-expression, that’s all great, but so is knowing when to stop. We’re all painfully aware that that’s been a missing feature, and an hour in I just couldn’t watch any more. The film clips were good, entertaining, not actually terribly novel (like I said, it’s been more than 50 years), but what was missing overwhelmed what was there if you weren’t just having a party in the rearview mirror.

I’d have welcomed though hearing more from everyone’s non-frugging parents. And more recognition of what you got wrong, how you’ve noticed it at this point. If you’ve noticed it. Review Title: Nice footage but it’s endless Boomers partying in the mirror Rating: 2.0 --------------------------------------------------
reference_summary:
Three Colors: Blue Juliette Binoche (Actor), Zbigniew Zamachowski (Actor), Krzysztof Kieslowski (Director, Writer) & 0 more Rated: R Format: DVD Movies & TV, Genre for Featured Categories, Drama ["The first installment of the late Polish director Krzysztof Kieslowski's trilogy on Liberty, Equality, and Fraternity, the three colors of the French flag. Blue is the most somber of the three, a movie dominated by feelings of grief. As the film begins, a"] {'Format': 'NTSC', 'Contributor': 'Claude Duneton, Edward Zebrowski, Zbigniew Zamachowski, Florence Pernel, Benoît Régent, Juliette Binoche, Marin Karmitz, Philippe Volter, Agnieszka Holland, Julie Delpy, Florence Vignon, Krzysztof Piesiewicz, Charlotte Véry, Slawomir Idziak, Emmanuelle Riva, Hugues Quester, Hélène Vincent, Krzysztof KieslowskiClaude Duneton, Edward Zebrowski, Zbigniew Zamachowski, Florence Pernel, Benoît Régent, Juliette Binoche, Marin Karmitz, Philippe Volter, Agnieszka Holland, Julie Delpy, Florence Vignon, Krzysztof Piesiewicz, Charlotte Véry, Slawomir Idziak, Emmanuelle Riva, Hugues… See more', 'Language': 'Unqualified (DTS ES 6.1)', 'Runtime': '1 hour and 38 minutes', 'Is Discontinued By Manufacturer': 'No', 'MPAA rating': 'R (Restricted)', 'Package Dimensions': '7.1 x 5.42 x 0.58 inches; 2.88 Ounces', 'Director': 'Krzysztof Kieslowski', 'Media Format': 'NTSC', 'Run time': '1 hour and 38 minutes', 'Actors': 'Juliette Binoche, Zbigniew Zamachowski, Julie Delpy, Benoît Régent, Florence Pernel', 'Producers': 'Marin Karmitz', 'Studio': 'Imports', 'Writers': 'Agnieszka Holland, Edward Zebrowski, Krzysztof Kieslowski, Krzysztof Piesiewicz, Slawomir Idziak'} I've seen this movie many times since 1995, but last night I watched it for the first time as an artist and single mother, and I realize I hadn't appreciated before the costs of her liberty, the value of the liberty, or the cruelty inherent in the art that carried her along after her daughter's death, the genuine death of her marriage, even (to twist the knife) the loss of her mother's memory. He went right to the joint, Kieslowski did. I couldn't watch it all, this time.

I don't think the blue mobile was her daughter's, by the way. I accept that she was the composer, and that for her there was a synaesthesia with the music and the blue lights. I expect the blue room was her composing room, and that the mobile was a thing from her art, which is why in the end she took it along. She had to; she needed it. The music needed it. a sharp choice of story for the theme Good Night, and Good Luck (Widescreen Edition) David Strathairn (Actor), Patricia Clarkson (Actor) Rated: PG Format: DVD Movies & TV, Studio Specials, Warner Home Video, Television ['Good Night and Good Luck (DVD) (WS)', "In the early 1950's, the threat of Communism created an air of paranoia in the United States and exploiting those fears was Senator Joseph McCarthy. CBS reporter Edward R. Murrow and his producer Fred W. Friendly decided to take a stand and challenge.", ']]>'] {'Genre': 'Documentary, Drama, Historical', 'Format': 'Black & White, Closed-captioned, Color, NTSC, Subtitled, Widescreen, Dolby', 'Contributor': 'Frank Langella, Jeff Daniels, Ben Cosgrove, Alex Borstein, Tate Donovan, Jennifer Todd, Mark Cuban, Matt Brandon Ross, Robert Downey Jr., David Strathairn, Steven Soderbergh, Patricia Clarkson, George Clooney, Ray Wise, Marion Kodama Yue, Robert John Burke, Todd Wagner, Marc Butan, Reed Diamond, Rose Abdoo, Jeff SkollFrank Langella, Jeff Daniels, Ben Cosgrove, Alex Borstein, Tate Donovan, Jennifer Todd, Mark Cuban, Matt Brandon Ross, Robert Downey Jr., David Strathairn, Steven Soderbergh, Patricia Clarkson, George Clooney, Ray Wise, Marion Kodama Yue, Robert John Burke, Todd Wagner… See more', 'Initial release date': '2006-05-23', 'Language': 'English (Dolby Digital 5.1), Unqualified', 'Is Discontinued By Manufacturer': 'No', 'MPAA rating': 'PG (Parental Guidance Suggested)', 'Product Dimensions': '7.5 x 5.5 x 0.53 inches; 2.4 Ounces', 'Item model number': '73678', 'Director': 'George Clooney', 'Media Format': 'Black & White, Closed-captioned, Color, NTSC, Subtitled, Widescreen, Dolby', 'Run time': '1 hour and 33 minutes', 'Release date': 'May 23, 2006', 'Actors': 'David Strathairn, Patricia Clarkson, George Clooney, Jeff Daniels, Robert Downey Jr.', 'Subtitles': 'English, Spanish, French', 'Producers': 'Steven Soderbergh, George Clooney, Ben Cosgrove, Marion Kodama Yue, Jennifer Todd', 'Studio': 'Studio Distribution Services', 'Writers': 'George Clooney, Marion Kodama Yue', 'Number of discs': '1'} It's very pretty, I'll say that for it, and the acting's certainly pro. That b/w process they used is terrifically lush, almost Max Factor.

Beyond that, though...boy, this is Journalism Heroes 101. The McCarthy story's a great one and Murrow was a serious guy, but the story's reduced to semaphore for this thing, a series of journalistic cliches. All the President's Men did much better, and that was with Woodward writing his patented Fantasy Internal Dialogue of High Officials. I'm sure the excuse goes that it's a movie, it's supposed to entertain and teach people who've never heard of Joe McCarthy, but that's all messed up. If they've never heard of Joe McCarthy, you want to serve up a shovelful of reality, not gleanings.

The acting-to-newsreel trick's a nice one, but it doesn't compensate for the thinness of the storytelling or the punch-pulling with the elbow out to Mars (there's a suicide? I'm shocked!). If you're not just looking for eye candy, try actual books instead on this subject. There's no end of books on both McCarthy and CBS -- I think Fred Friendly wrote one of his own. Dumbed-down history for the NCLB era {'Subtitles': ['None available'], 'Directors': ['Guy Maddin'], 'Producers': ['Jody Shapiro', 'Phyllis Laing'], 'Starring': ['Ann Savage', 'Louis Negin', 'Darcy Fehr']} I totally believe everything he told me about Winnipeg. I believe the snow, the sleepiness, the ectoplasm, the lost and benumbed waspiness of it, the wackadoodle mom, the, yeah, I buy it. I still don't want to go there but it's nice that it's dear to someone. I believe it. {'Subtitles': ['None available'], 'Directors': ['Wendy Keys'], 'Producers': ['Edgar B. Howard', 'Wendy Keys'], 'Starring': ['Milton Glaser'], 'Studio': ['Arthouse Films/Curiously Bright']} I hadn't realized how responsible Glaser was for the look and feel of my childhood. I don't much like it -- it makes me feel queasy -- but I appreciate and understand what he was doing, and it's a fine doc. A must for design students, I'd think. Rock on. {'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Louis Malle'], 'Producers': ['Fred Berner'], 'Starring': ['Andre Gregory', 'Brooke Smith', 'Julianne Moore'], 'Studio': ['Sony Pictures Classics']} This is magnificent, even better than I remember. You forget that Wally Shawn can act like this -- what a curdled, potent character. (Where has he been?) The conceits aren't bothersome, they're fine, it's really too painful to watch all at once. It's really theatre, it's film but it's theatre. I don't know how they made that work. even better than I remember Sunflower (English Subtitled) International, Arthouse, Passionate, Sad ["An Oscar nominee for Best Score (Henry Mancini), SUNFLOWER is a grandly emotional melodrama featuring a stunning performance from Sophia Loren.In another of the actress's great collaborations with director Vittorio De Sica (THE BICYCLE THIEF), Loren plays Giovanna, a steel-willed Italian woman on a desperate search to find her husband Antonio (Marcello Mastroianni), who has gone missing on the WWII battlefields of Russia. Making the grueling overland journey years after the end of the war, she tracks Antonio down and finds him a changed man. This heart-wrenching reunion will forever alter the course of their lives."] {'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['None available'], 'Directors': ['Vittorio De Sica'], 'Producers': ['Carlo Ponti', 'Arthur Cohn', 'Giorgi Mdivani', 'Joseph E. Levine'], 'Starring': ['Sophia Loren', 'Marcello Mastroianni']} Underused actors, syrupy plot. Two Stars A Special Day (English Subtitled) Drama, Arthouse, Compelling, Sentimental ['Italian dream team Sophia Loren and Marcello Mastroianni are cast against type and deliver two of the finest performances of their careers in this moving, quietly subversive drama set in Rome on the historic day when Benito Mussolini and the city first rolled out the red carpet for Adolf Hitler.'] {'Content advisory': ['Nudity', 'violence', 'alcohol use', 'smoking', 'sexual content'], 'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['None available'], 'Directors': ['Ettore Scola'], 'Producers': ['Carlo Ponti'], 'Starring': ['Marcello Mastroianni', 'Sophia Loren']} it's a short story, not a movie. A very, very good short story that makes clear how wildly underused both these actors were throughout their careers, all this distraction about sex symbols. very good short story that makes clear how wildly underused both ... {'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Bernardo Bertolucci'], 'Producers': ['Alberto Grimaldi'], 'Starring': ['Marlon Brando', 'Maria Schneider'], 'Studio': ['MGM Domestic Television Distri']} Why, why did I think this would be a good idea. This is what directors did in the 70s because the internet hadn't been invented yet. Urgh. why did I think this would be a good idea. This is what directors did in the ... {'Content advisory': ['Violence', 'smoking', 'foul language', 'sexual content'], 'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Stanley Kramer'], 'Producers': ['Stanley Kramer'], 'Starring': ['Spencer Tracy', 'Fredric March', 'Gene Kelly']} All that shade and it's still too hot. Grand movie. Yes, you should watch it. {'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Joanne McGrath'], 'Starring': ['Dermot Bannan'], 'Studio': ['Indigenius']} I really did want to like this — the projects are interesting, the homeowners are hugely sympathetic, and Dermot’s quite likeable at first blush. But over and over he takes to bullying and talking over his female clients until I want to shove him out of the room and have a shouting match with him myself. I’m sure the idea was to make a bit of theatre here, but it’s in no way amusing.

Apart from which, unfortunately, he just isn’t that good an architect. He’s all right, I guess, but it’s all much of a muchness, the same standard high-end modernism-inflected boxes with big windows. Lots of talk about wanting to preserve the charm of some wreck and then delivering some atrium-ridden nightmare to heat. It’s always an improvement, and certainly things could’ve gone much worse, but...I’m sorry, Dermot, you’re not an artist, and frankly your interiors and additions often don’t really suit the old buildings. For the love of god, stop bullying the woman clients {'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['David Batty'], 'Producers': ['Simon Fuller', 'Michael Caine', 'Dick Clement', 'Ian La Frenais', "Fodhla Cronin O'Reilly"], 'Starring': ['David Bailey', 'Michael Caine', 'Joan Collins'], 'Studio': ['Gravitas Ventures']} I mean....

I get that at the end of your life you want to look back, see what it was, remember why it was, relive the good times. It’s just that the rest of us have had to live your particular good time along with you for over fifty bleeding years, and it’s been incredibly damaging. Freedom, self-expression, that’s all great, but so is knowing when to stop. We’re all painfully aware that that’s been a missing feature, and an hour in I just couldn’t watch any more. The film clips were good, entertaining, not actually terribly novel (like I said, it’s been more than 50 years), but what was missing overwhelmed what was there if you weren’t just having a party in the rearview mirror.

I’d have welcomed though hearing more from everyone’s non-frugging parents. And more recognition of what you got wrong, how you’ve noticed it at this point. If you’ve noticed it. Nice footage but it’s endless Boomers partying in the mirror
profile:
**Updated User Profile Summary:**

- **Film Appreciation:** The user values deep, emotional storytelling in drama, focusing on complex themes like grief, liberty, and personal sacrifice.

- **Director and Actor Preference:** They admire filmmakers such as Krzysztof Kieslowski and Guy Maddin, along with classic actors like Spencer Tracy and Sophia Loren, indicating a consistent preference for nuanced narratives.

- **Viewing Experience:** Engaging reflectively, the user revisits impactful titles and embraces short films that resonate on multiple levels.

- **Artistic Interpretation:** They maintain a critical perspective, valuing films that provoke thought on themes and aesthetics, and expressing concerns over narrative integrity.

- **Thematic Engagement:** The user connects with narratives exploring freedom's costs and creativity, particularly involving motherhood and personal loss.

- **Critical Engagement with Film:** Their critical approach is reinforced by a recent negative review emphasizing issues with character dynamics and narrative depth, showcasing intolerance for superficiality and a desire for reflective storytelling.

- **Documentary Engagement:** Interest in impactful documentaries is increasing, especially those that offer personal resonance.

- **Theater and Film Interplay:** The user continues to explore the intersection of theater and film, seeking complex characters and emotional intensity in both art forms, while expressing disappointment when expectations are unmet.

- **Recent Interaction:** They recently critiqued a documentary for its lack of depth and consideration of broader perspectives, illustrating their preference for thoughtful narratives over nostalgic indulgence.
